Award.AwardTitle: Vibrational Spectroscopy with Subnanometer Electron Beams: Correlating Chemistry and Atomic Structure on Nanoparticle Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professors Peter Crozier and Peter Rez at Arizona State University to develop a tool for probing the nanoscale chemistry of materials surfaces. This will provide an approach for understanding the way in which nanoparticles interact and influence their environment. The knowledge that is expected to emerge from this work could have wide applications in many fields where nanoparticle surfaces are important including catalysis, sensors and the life sciences. Graduate students and undergraduate researchers are expected to gain valuable training at the interface of nanomaterials and chemistry. Educational outreach programs associated with this project are targeting K-12 children with emphasis on Hispanic and Native American student sub-populations.

The project exploits new developments in the field of transmission electron microscopy and electron energy-loss spectroscopy which permit vibrational spectroscopy to be performed with a focused electron beam of 0.1 nanometer in diameter. A major goal is to develop methodologies for probing vibrational surface states with high spatial resolution without significantly damaging the surface or removing surface adsorbates. A combination of experimental and modelling work is employed to optimize spectral acquisition and analysis techniques. The ultimate spatial resolution is influenced by the length scale of the electrostatic interaction between the electron beam and the sample. The spatial resolution and sensitivity of the approach for detecting a number of common chemical functional groups on a variety of metal and oxide nanoparticles surfaces will be determined. This project will provide the scientific community with a new method for probing fundamental chemical processes with nanometer resolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atoms in molecules and materials are constantly vibrating and these vibrations influence many processes that are important to technology such as heat transfer and chemical reactions. Atomic vibrations are related to the strength of the bonding between atoms and the resonant frequency of the vibration changes when we change the bonding. Sound waves moving through a material are a well-known manifestation of atomic vibrations. There are other types of vibrational modes that can be excited by illuminating the sample with infrared radiation. The complexity of the bonding in molecules and materials results in each system having many vibrational modes. The atomic vibrational modes in materials are called phonons. In this project, we developed a new technique to probe and sense vibrational modes in materials and molecules. The approach employs a form of electron spectroscopy available in electron microscopes. In a modern electron microscope, the electron can be focused down to a tiny spot which can be precisely positioned on an atom  or group of atoms. This allows us to investigate how the vibrational modes and chemical bonding varies on a very fine, atomic length scale.

During this project, we were able to demonstrate, for the first time, that it is possible to perform atomic resolution vibrational spectroscopy. This significant breakthrough now provides scientists and engineers with a new tool to probe vibrational modes in molecules and materials at the finest possible length scale. We also showed that the electron beam can interact with the sample in many ways allowing modes of different character to be probed. A direct collision between the electron and an atom excites all modes in the system.  On the other hand, a glancing collision only stimulates a subset of modes similar to those excited by infrared illumination. Many critical questions in chemistry and nanomaterials can now be explored and understood at a much deeper level especially at surfaces and interfaces.  This new technique will impact many areas of physical and biological science and will lead to improvements in important applications areas such as clean energy, catalysis and thermal processes.

The project provided excellent opportunities for training graduate and undergraduate students in advanced science and technology. It also provided support for post-doctoral training during the project. All trainees in the project have gone on to successful jobs in high tech companies or government research labs.
